column3:
Portal hypertensive duodenopathy - mosaic/reticular pattern, red spots, congestion, cherry-red spots, background portal hypertension
Reactive / chemical duodenitis - bile pooling, bile staining, mucosal edema
NSAID-related duodenopathy - multiple small erosions, clean-based erosive pattern
Stress-related inflammation - diffuse erythema + erosions in critically ill/ICU patients
Celiac-type mucosal injury - scalloped folds, nodularity, villous-appearing blunting
Congestive / venous duodenopathy - dusky mucosa, congested vessels, swollen folds, right heart failure context)
Radiation-related changes - patchy telangiectasia, pallor, friability with prior radiation history
Infective duodenitis - ulcers, exudate, friability; context of fever or immune suppression
Not assigning etiology - purely descriptive reporting

column3:
Gastric_Atrophy_Kimura-Takemoto_850x504.png
Atrophic borders are indicated by a dotted line. 
A: C1 (Limited to the antrum)
B: C2 (Limited to the minor area of the lesser curvature of the body)
C: C3 (In the major area of the lesser curvature of the body but does not extend beyond the cardia)
D: O1 (Extends to the fundus over the cardia. Atrophic border of the body lies between the lesser curvature and anterior wall)
E: O2 (Atrophic border of the body lies on the anterior wall)
F: O3 (Widespread with the border between the anterior wall and greater curvature)

column2: Endoscopic Appearance of the Obstructed Segment

column21: Restart / reposition scope after suctioning food debris

column3:
Quick Visual Rules
    • Smooth + same color + multiple in fundus → think fundic gland
    • Red + lobulated + erosion → think hyperplastic
    • Irregular surface or margins → treat as adenomatous-suspicious
    • Yellowish, firm, round → consider NET
    • Diffuse polyps → think syndromic

column18: GOV1 (Esophageal varices extending along lesser curvature)
F1 – Small, straight or mildly tortuous varices
column19: F2 – Enlarged, tortuous varices occupying part of lumen
column20: F3 – Large, nodular or tumor-like varices occupying lumen

column3:
Reactive / chemical gastropathy (bile reflux): bile staining, foveolar hyperemia, antral predominance
NSAID-related gastropathy: numerous small erosions, clean-based erosions, antral > body involvement
Stress-related gastropathy: diffuse erythema + erosions in critically ill/ICU patients
Radiation gastropathy: patchy telangiectasia, pallor, friability, known gastric radiation field
Congestive / venous gastropathy: dusky mucosa, swollen congested folds, cherry-red spots, cardiac/venous congestion
H. pylori–associated gastritis pattern: mottled erythema, nodularity, loss of RAC, antral dominance
Not assigning etiology: purely descriptive report — recommended when uncertain

Mild PHG  :- mosaic (“snake-skin”) pattern only, without red spots or bleeding
Severe PHG :- mosaic pattern plus red/cherry-red spots (numerous or confluent) and/or active oozing/bleeding (or presence of diffuse friability)

column22: Suggest repeat endoscopy based on severity

column18: Suspected H. pylori (endoscopic appearance or clinical)

column3:
Antral nodularity --> highly suggestive
Diffuse erythema --> antrum ± body
Multiple small erosions --> antral
Atrophic patches / intestinal metaplasia --> possible chronic infection

Sydney protocol:
Take ≥2 antral biopsies (lesser curvature + greater curvature)
Take ≥1 corpus/body biopsy. 
Label jars separately — antrum vs corpus

column18: Irregular mucosal/vascular pattern in antrum (suggests intestinal metaplasia)
column19: Patchy brownish/red areas with altered microvascularity (Suspected- active gastritis)
column21: Regular collecting venules visible (RAC present)  suggests H. pylori negative

column23: Pooling of fluid due to stiffness

column3:
Parasites_Table_1000x800.png
Practical Endoscopy Notes
    • Live worm visualization: Hookworm, Ascaris, Enterobius, Taenia.
    • Mucosal patterns suggestive, organism not seen: Giardia, Microsporidia, Cryptosporidium.
    • Colonoscopic nodules / polyps: Think Schistosoma, Trichuris.
    • Rectal itching + worms: Enterobius.
    • Immunocompromised host: Strongyloides, CMV overlap, protozoa
Parasites_4in1_1000x900.png
column18: Suspected Ascaris - Long, pale, snake-like worm (10–30 cm)
column19: Suspected Strongyloides larvae - Thin thread-like moving worm (<1 cm)
column20: Suspected Hookworm - Short curved worm attached to mucosa
column21: Suspected Anisakis - Coiled single worm in stomach with edema
column22: Suspected Tapeworm segment - Flat white segment / ribbon-like fragment
column23: Suspected Giardia - Multiple tiny motile organisms

column3:
Mild PHG : mosaic pattern ± red dots)
Severe PHG : diffuse redness, cherry red spots, black-brown spots, active oozing)

Mild : scope passes with ease
Moderate : scope passes with gentle pressure
Severe : scope cannot pass
